column1: Friend et al. (1986) isolated a cDNA that detects a chromosomal segment having the properties of the gene at the retinoblastoma locus. The gene was found to be expressed in many tumor types
column2: but no RNA transcript was found in retinoblastomas or osteosarcomas. The locus spanned at least 70 kb of DNA. Friend et al. (1986) started with a 1.5 kb DNA sequence which could detect deletions involving 13q14 in 3 of 37 retinoblastomas. They then used chromosome walking techniques to isolate and map 30 kb of surrounding genomic DNA. One of the single-copy fragments recognized a DNA sequence in the mouse genome and also in human chromosome 13. The conservation of this DNA sequence between mouse and humans suggested that the cloned fragment contained a coding exon of a gene. Therefore
column3: they tested the ability of this fragment to hybridize to RNA derived from retinoblastoma cells and from human retinal cells. They found that indeed it recognized a 4.7-kb RNA transcript in the retinal cell line but that this transcript was not detectable in 4 retinoblastomas.

column1: As outlined by Cavenee (1986)
column2: when the cDNA described by Friend et al. (1986) was used as a probe to screen RNA samples from different tumor types
column3: it was shown to hybridize to all of those tested except retinoblastomas and retinoblastoma-associated osteosarcomas. Furthermore
column4: use of this cDNA to analyze the genomic structure of its homologous locus in 50 retinoblastomas or associated osteosarcomas showed that about 30% had somatically altered genomic loci. These alterations took the form of fragments of altered mobility (suggesting gene rearrangements)
column5: underrepresented fragments (suggesting heterozygous deletions)
column6: and missing fragments (suggesting homozygous deletions). Since one of the homozygous deletions was entirely contained within the genomic locus homologous to the cDNA probe
column7: it was suggested that this expressed gene was indeed the RB1 gene.

column1: Dryja et al. (1986) isolated a cDNA fragment derived from human retinal mRNA that detected a locus within 13q14 that is often deleted in retinoblastoma.

Lee et al. (1987) prepared a rabbit antiserum against the RB protein studied by Horsthemke et al. (1987) and showed that it was present in all cell lines expressing normal RB mRNA but was not detected in 5 retinoblastoma cell lines. column2: indicating that it is a phosphoprotein. Biochemical fractionation and immunofluorescence studies demonstrated that most of the protein is located in the nucleus. Furthermore
column3: the protein was retained by and could be eluted from DNA-cellulose columns
column4: suggesting a DNA binding activity.

column1: Gene duplication and domain accretion are thought to be the major mechanism for the emergence of novel genes during evolution. (2003) reported that the USP6 oncogene is derived from the chimeric fusion of 2 genes
column2: USP32 (607740) and TBC1D3 (607741). USP32 is an ancient highly conserved gene
column3: whereas TBC1D3 is derived from a recent segmental duplication that is absent in most other mammals and shows rapid amplification and dispersal through the primate lineage. column4: after proliferation of the TBC1D3 segmental duplication in the primate lineage. Paulding et al. (2003) determined that the full-length USP6 gene encodes a 1
column5: 406-amino acid protein. Amino acids 1 to 496 are derived from TBC1D3 and encompass a TBC domain. Amino acids 501 to 1406 are derived from USP32 and encompass a ubiquitin-specific protease domain. In contrast to the broad expression patterns of USP32 and TBC1D3
column6: RT-PCR analysis showed that expression of USP6 is testis-specific
column7: a pattern proposed for genes implicated in the emergence of reproductive barriers. The authors concluded that the sudden emergence of chimeric proteins
column8: such as that encoded by USP6

column1: AKAP9_SNP;0.0021896977991343;AKAP9;"A-KINASE ANCHOR PROTEIN 9; AKAP9";live;"Proper synaptic function requires accurate localization of appropriate ion channels and neurotransmitter receptors to the postsynaptic site. column6: to a lesser degree in heart and placenta

(1998) concluded that yotiao is an NR1-binding protein that is potentially involved in the cytoskeletal attachment of NMDA receptors.

column1: LMO1_SNP;0.002047971555642;LMO1;"LIM DOMAIN ONLY 1; LMO1";live;"Boehm et al. (1988) and Greenberg et al. (1989) studied a previously identified translocation t(11;14)(p15;q11) associated with T cells in acute lymphoblastic leukemia (613065). The translocation involves the TCR-delta locus (see 186810) on 14q11 and also a transcribed sequence on 11p15. They found that the gene on 11p15 is normally expressed in rhombomeres of the developing hindbrain. The gene product
column2: designated rhombosine or rhombotin
column3: has 155 amino acids and no homology to any previously described protein.

column1: Because human and mouse rhombotin are virtually identical in derived protein sequence
column2: rendering it difficult to identify functionally important regions or motifs
column3: Boehm et al. (1990) isolated and compared rhombotin sequences from disparate species. They showed a sequence that is highly homologous to that of human and mouse rhombotin in Drosophila DNA. This comparison and others suggested that rhombotin
column4: which lacks a DNA-binding homeodomain
column5: may belong to a new class of transcriptional regulators that modulate transcription via intermolecular competitive binding to certain DNA-binding transcription factors. The structure of the predicted rhombotin protein suggests that it consists of 2 tandemly arranged cysteine-rich regions
column6: which were subsequently identified in 3 transcription factors appended to putative DNA binding and activation domains
column7: wherein they were termed LIM domains. The function of LIM domains may be in protein-protein interaction. LIM domains show homology to zinc-binding proteins and to iron-sulfur centers of ferredoxins. Consistent with its close structural homology to the human gene
column8: the mouse homolog Ttg1 maps to chromosome 7
column9: distal to the beta-globin locus (Angel et al.

column1: Boehm et al. (1991) isolated 2 homologs of the rhombotin gene. Rhombotin-2 (RBTN2; 180385) is located close to the T-ALL breakpoint cluster region on 11p13. This was determined by mapping to chromosome 11 by hybridization to a somatic cell that contained only human chromosome 11 and thereafter by hybridizing the human rhombotin exon-2-specific probe to cosmid clones spanning about 100 kb around the T-ALL breakpoint cluster region. Rhom-2 in the mouse is similar to the human homolog. Boehm et al. (1991) identified a third rhombotin-like gene (RBTN3; 180386) and determined that it is not situated on chromosome 11. It shows

column1: GLI1_SNP;0.0016206956646148;GLI1;"GLI FAMILY ZINC FINGER 1; GLI1";live;"Kinzler et al. (1987) identified a gene
column2: which they called glioma-associated oncogene (GLI)
column3: that is amplified more than 50-fold in a malignant glioma. The gene was expressed at high levels in the original tumor and its derived cell line. Kinzler et al. (1988) extended this work by cloning the GLI complementary DNA. Analysis of the nucleotide sequence demonstrated that the gene contains 5 repeats of the DNA-binding consensus sequence (zinc finger). The zinc fingers contain sequence elements that place the GLI gene product among the Kruppel (Kr) family of zinc finger proteins (see 165230). (The German word 'Kruppel' means 'cripple' or 'dwarf.') The Drosophila gene is a member of the gap class of segmentation genes; thoracic and anterior abdominal segments fail to form in Kr mutant embryos. Kr encodes a chromatin-associated phosphoprotein that contains 5 zinc fingers with a consensus sequence connecting the histidine of 1 finger to the cysteine of the next. Conservation of the contiguous stretch of nucleotides encoding this H-C link allowed cloning of Kruppel-related genes from D. melanogaster
column4: mouse
column5: and frog
column6: by hybridization with Kr cDNA at low stringency. Each of these Kr family members were shown to be expressed in embryonic cells
column7: suggesting a role for them in normal development. Northern analysis revealed that GLI is expressed in embryonal carcinoma cells but not in most adult tissue. A fragile site of the folic acid type has been described at 12q13. In addition
column8: translocations involving this region of chromosome 12 have been described in myxoid liposarcoma (151900) and salivary gland tumors. Southern blot analysis with probes for INT1 (164820) and IGF1 (147440)
column9: both of which are located on chromosome 12

column3: which they they called CAK. The deduced 913-amino acid protein has a calculated molecular mass of 101 kD. It has an N-terminal signal sequence
column4: followed by an extracellular domain
column5: a transmembrane region
column6: and a cytoplasmic receptor tyrosine kinase domain. The N-terminal extracellular domain shares similarity with phospholipid-binding sequences found in cell adhesion molecules
column7: such as neuronal A5 antigen and factors V (F5; 612309) and VIII (F8; 300841)
column8: and it has 7 cysteines
column9: 4 potential N-glycosylation sites
column10: and a furin (FUR; 136950) cleavage site (RxRR). The C-terminal kinase domain contains motifs characteristic of a receptor tyrosine kinase
column11: including a canonical GxGxxG sequence of the ATP-binding loop and 4 tyrosine phosphorylation sites
column12: 3 of which may be autophosphorylated. Northern blot analysis detected a 5-kb transcript in all tissues examined
column13: with highest expression in brain and lung. CAK expression was also detected in mouse brain and in several human cell lines.

column1: By screening a keratinocyte cDNA library with the catalytic domain of TRKA (NTRK1; 191315)
column2: followed by screening fetal brain and keratinocyte cDNA libraries
column3: Di Marco et al. (1993) cloned a splice variant of DDR1 that they designated TRKE. The deduced 876-amino acid protein has an N-terminal signal sequence
column4: followed by an extracellular domain with 5 consensus N-glycosylation sites and 7 cysteines
column5: a transmembrane domain
column6: and a cytoplasmic domain with a kinase catalytic domain that includes an ATP-binding site and a putative autophosphorylation site. Northern blot analysis detected a 3.9-kb TRKE transcript in human keratinocytes and in all adult and fetal human tissues examined except liver.

column1: Using PCR
column2: Laval et al. (1994) cloned a splice variant of DDR1 that they called RTK6 from a human epithelial ovarian cancer cell line. The deduced 876-amino acid protein

column10: lung
column11: liver
column12: muscle
column14: and pancreas. RT-PCR detected expression of both DDR and RTK6 in placenta and in all ovarian cell lines tested. In situ hybridization detected RTK6 in epithelial cells of human ovary
column19: and gray matter of fetal brain. RTK6 was expressed at high levels in moderately and poorly differentiated malignant ovarian tumors and at lower levels in normal
column21: and borderline tumors. Western blot analysis detected RTK6 at an apparent molecular mass of 140 kD

column1: SLC34A2_DEL;0.0010730832621768;SLC34A2;"SOLUTE CARRIER FAMILY 34 (SODIUM/PHOSPHATE COTRANSPORTER)
column2: MEMBER 2; SLC34A2";live;"Inorganic phosphate absorption from the small intestine and reabsorption from the renal tubule play key roles in the control of inorganic phosphate metabolism and the maintenance of phosphate homeostasis. A number of sodium-dependent phosphate transporters have been identified. Although functionally related
column3: these phosphate transporters are structurally distinct and can be broadly grouped into 3 subtypes based on sequence identity. Type 1 transporters
column4: such as NPT1 (SLC17A1; 182308)
column5: are found mainly in kidney and do not appear to be regulated by dietary phosphate levels. Type 2 transporters can be subdivided into 2 groups based on sequence similarity and tissue distribution. One group
column6: which includes NaPi3 (SLC34A1; 182309)
column7: consists of transporters that are found almost exclusively in the renal proximal tubule
column8: whereas the second group consists of transporters that are more widely distributed. Type 3 transporters can also function as membrane receptors for primate retroviruses. By searching an EST database for cDNAs that show sequence similarity to NaPi3
column9: Feild et al. (1999) identified a human small intestine cDNA encoding the novel phosphate transporter SLC34A2
column10: which they named NaPi3B. They isolated a full-length SLC34A2 cDNA from both human small intestine and lung cDNAs. The deduced 690-amino acid SLC34A2 protein is a type 2 phosphate transporter. It contains 8 predicted transmembrane domains and a cysteine-rich N-terminal region. SLC34A2 shares 78% amino acid identity with the mouse sodium-dependent phosphate transporter IIb. Functional studies showed that SLC34A2 is a sodium-dependent phosphate transporter that is strongly sensitive to pH
column11: with phosphate uptake increased at more acidic pH. Northern blot analysis detected a 4.2-kb SLC34A2 transcript in several human tissues of epithelial origin; kidney also contained high levels of a 2.4-kb transcript. SLC34A2 was most abundantly expressed in lung
column12: with moderate expression in kidney

column2: chromosomal location

The gene is transcribed in a pattern overlapping that of GATA4 (600576). Transcripts for both of these genes are prominent in heart
column4: pancreas

(1996) commented that GATA6 is a prime candidate for a gene that regulates the differentiative state of vascular smooth muscle cells.

column1: <Subhead> MORF/CBP Fusion Gene

Panagopoulos et al. (2001) reported a novel t(10;16)(q22;p13) chromosomal translocation in a childhood acute myelogenous leukemia (AML-M5a) leading to a MORF-CBP (600140) chimera. RT-PCR experiments yielded in-frame MORF-CBP and CBP-MORF fusion transcripts. Genomic analyses revealed that the breaks were close to Alu elements in intron 16 of MORF and intron 2 of CBP and that duplications had occurred near the breakpoints.
